PRINT/PDF

Research documentation & publishing system

Dossiers

The Hybrid Publishing Consortium’s Dossiers are composed of a selection and arrangement of 500-2000 words working papers/reports, plus an introduction explaining the composition of the dossier and the articulation between its different parts (reports). The reports can be commissioned texts as well as pre-existing ones, they are multi-format: lists, essays, notes, slide shows, etc.

In order to be able to publish a report in several Dossiers, the system for editing/organizing/archiving the reports needs to be flexible.

The reports will be stored in a GitHub repository, each one in a folder composed of the content in an html file, a folder for images and other documents, and a css file (when necessary).

Diagram

Single source, yet medium specific

To tune parts of the reports in relation with a specific medium (for instance only for print), we can use specific class names (convention needed for that) that will then be displayed or not depending on the format.

HTML style guide

If we want ePub-ready files, we should write in a compatible way (ePub is XHTML). A solution for that is Polyglot Markup. We could also run a validator (with HTML5 Validator, that can be run with Travis CI), which validates the code that is pushed on GitHub. And use transpect to convert HTML5 to XHTML.

Hybrid design

The HPC documentation and publications’ design is inspired by the following notions: multi-format, hybridity, flexibility, multiplicity, transformation. It consists of a design system, a series of guidelines, responsive and media-specific CSS styles, and a set of Free and Open source materials and tools, that can be modified to fit with specific uses. In a Free and Open Source spirit, it promotes a wide, free and shared distribution of knowledge. It is thus taking into account both accessible and high-costs formats, big and small screens, PDFs for A4 personal printer as well as Offset-ready files…

Layout rules

Two more columns with slideshows and poster-like documents need to be integrated.

Structure of the body of the html file


<body>
    <!-- FUTURE SCENARIO: THIS WILL BE PART OF THE TEMPLATE: -->
    <!-- FUTURE SCENARIO: it will automatically get the right infos from the dossiers json file(s) -->

    <div class="container">
        <div class="research-wrapper">

    <!-- HPC DOSSIERS HEADER (LOGO) -->
    <nav class="navbar">
        <div class="navbar-header">
            <div class="navbar-logo">
                <a href="/">
                    <div style="height: 94px; width: 179px" id="randomLogo"></div>
                    <!--<img src="../../static/animated-logo3-small.gif" alt="hpc-logo">-->
                    <p class="logo-dossiers"><span class="logo-header-shrinked">HPC </span>DOSSIERS</p>
                </a>
            </div>
            <!-- MAIN HEADING: PAGE TITLE -->
            <!-- (only one h1 on the page: here) -->
            <div id="report-title">
                <h1>TITLE</h1>
            </div>
        </div> <!-- END DIV navbar-header -->
    </nav>

    <!-- HACK TO MAKE IT WORK FINE :)-->
    <div id="empty-box-for-header1">
    </div>
    <div id="empty-box-for-header2">
    </div>

    <!-- SIDE INFORMATION ON THE REPORT-->
    <div id="report-info">
        <!-- date and author info -->
        <div id="report-date-author">
            <p id="report-date">2015</p>
            <p id="report-authors"><!-- use commas if several authors -->The Authors</p>
        </div>
        <!-- abstract -->
        <div id="report-abstract">
            <p>The abstract</p>
        </div>
    </div>
    <div class="report-content">
        <!-- REPORT MENU -->
        <aside>
            <div class="TOC-wrapper">
                <a class="scroll-collapse-menu" data-toggle="collapse" href="#toc-hidden">
                    <img class="toc-menu" src="../../static/menu-icon-hpc.png" alt="menu" />
                </a>
                <div class="collapse" id="toc-hidden">
                    <h3 class="toc-title">Contents</h3>
                    <ul>
                        <li><a href="#1">First subheading</a></li>
                        <li><a href="#2">Second subheading</a></li>
                        <li><a href="#3">Third subheading</a></li>
                    </ul>
                </div>
                <!-- arrow to the top of the page -->
                <a href="#"><p class="arrow-top">TOP <span class="arrow-style">￪</span></p></a>
                <!-- RETURN arrow to the top of the page -->
                <a href="/"><p class="arrow-top-return"><span class="arrow-style">￩</span> RETURN</p></a>
            </div>
        </aside>
        <!-- HACK TO MAKE IT WORK FINE :)-->
        <div id="empty-box-for-aside" class="hidden">
        </div>

        <!-- FUTURE SCENARIO: HERE THE TEMPLATE WILL IMPORT THE DIFFERENT  -->

        <!-- REPORT -->
        <article>
            <!-- W3C's HTML5: "A section is a thematic grouping of content" -->
            <!-- Sections can be repeated -->
            <section>
                <h2 id="1">First subheading</h2>
                <p>Content of the paragraph. The first paragraph of a section has no indent. A paragraph (from the Ancient Greek παράγραφος paragraphos, "to write beside" or "written beside") is a group of sentences with one topic. It is also a self-contained unit of a discourse in writing dealing with a particular point or idea. A paragraph consists of more than one sentence. Though not required by the syntax of any language, paragraphs are usually an expected part of formal writing, used to organize longer prose. (Wikipedia)</p>
                <p>Content of the paragraph: the paragraphs following the first paragraph of a section have an indent.</p>
            </section>

            <section>
                <h2 id="2">Second subheading</h2>
                <!-- A FOOTNOTE! -->
                <p>Here we show an image<sup><a href="#fn1" id="r1">[1]</a></sup>:</p>
                <figure>
                    <img src="../../static/hybrid-publishing-consortium-logo.png" alt="hpc-logo">
                    <figcaption>Caption of the image</figcaption>
                </figure>
            </section>

            <section>
                <h2 id="3">Third subheading</h2>
                <p>Small images (three in the text width on big screens) next to each other</p>
                <div class="clear one-column">
                    <figure>
                        <img src="../../static/hybrid-publishing-consortium-logo.png" alt="hpc-logo">
                        <figcaption>Caption of the image</figcaption>
                    </figure>
                    <figure>
                        <img src="../../static/hybrid-publishing-consortium-logo.png" alt="hpc-logo">
                        <figcaption>Caption of the image</figcaption>
                    </figure>
                    <figure>
                        <img src="../../static/hybrid-publishing-consortium-logo.png" alt="hpc-logo">
                        <figcaption>Caption of the image</figcaption>
                    </figure>
                </div>
                <p>Small images, height of 100px, on top of each other, aligned on the left.</p>
                <div class="height100 img-left">
                    <figure>
                        <img src="../../static/hybrid-publishing-consortium-logo.png" alt="hpc-logo">
                        <figcaption>Caption of the image</figcaption>
                    </figure>
                    <figure>
                        <img src="../../static/hybrid-publishing-consortium-logo.png" alt="hpc-logo">
                        <figcaption>Caption of the image</figcaption>
                    </figure>
                </div>
            </section>

            <section id="footnotes">
                <h2>Notes:</h2>
                <p id="fn1"><a href="#r1">[1]</a> How awsome is that?</p>
            </section>
        </article><!-- END REPORT -->

    </div><!-- end div report-content -->

    <!-- HPC DOSSIERS FOOTER -->
    <footer>
        <a data-toggle="collapse" href="#footer-hidden">
          <p class="more">INFO</p>
        </a>
        <div class="footer-logos">
            <img src="../../static/EFRE-logo.png" alt="Europa">
            <img src="../../static/EuropafoerdertNds_farbig.png" alt="Niedersachsen">
            <img src="../../static/logo_leuphana-2.png" alt="Leuphana">
        </div>
        <div class="collapse" id="footer-hidden">
            <p>Contact: mail AT consortium.io</p>
            <p><a href="http://www.leuphana.de/en/site-notice-leuphana.html">Imprint</a></p>
            <p>© The authors | <a href="https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/de/">CC BY 3.0 DE</a></p>
            <p>The Hybrid Publishing Consortium is a project of the Hybrid Publishing Lab in collaboration with partners and associates. The Hybrid Publishing Lab is part of the Leuphana University of Lüneburg Innovation Incubator, financed by the European Regional Development Fund and co-funded by the German federal state of Lower Saxony.</p>
        </div>
    </footer>
    </div><!-- end div research-wrapper -->
    </div><!-- end div container -->

    <!-- CALLS THE JS -->
    <script src="../../js/all.min.js"></script>
</body>

Free and Open Source fonts

  • REGLO, a font by OSP Foundry, designed by Sebastien Sanfilippo to be streched. OFL
  • REGLO
  • Bagnard, also designed by Sebastien Sanfilippo, quite hype, display and very bold texts (but no italics… for the moment). OFL
  • Montserrat, a font by Julieta Ulanovsky, created to keep a trace of old posters and signs in the traditional neighborhood of Buenos Aires called Montserrat. OFL
  • Cotham, a sans serif grotesk font by Sebastien Sanfilippo. OFL
  • NotCourier Sans, monospace chopped by OSP. OFL
  • Charter, a serif typeface designed by Matthew Carter for Bitstream Inc. Foundry, donated in 1992 to another Consortium, the X Consortium, under an Open Source license. The font is based on 18th century characters designed by Pierre-Simon Fournier, and was optimized for printing on low-resolution laser printers of the 1980s. The encounter between the very fine design inspired by Fournier’s characters and the low resolution of the personal printing technologies makes it a real multi-format font that is very legible on both low and high-tech screen and print. License
  • Work Sans is a “superfamily” of fonts based on early Grotesques, designed by by Wei Huang with Metapolator. Some of its 10 weights were optimised for screen medium-sized text usage (14px-48px), the thinner and heavier for display use, and they also look fine on paper. But the superfamily doesn’t have italics… yet! OFL
  • Lato is a more complete family of fonts with many weights and italics, designed by Łukasz Dziedzic. It is described as “Male and female, serious but friendly. With the feeling of the Summer”… OFL

Icons for the research

Icons for the distribution (download buttons)

When several formats are released in an open context (download button on a web page for instance VS through proprietary software that limit the possibility of formats and reading devices), confusion often happens: on which tablet goes which format?

The use of specific icons for the different formats can help clarifying the types of files proposed:

  • - flowing ePub 2
  • - fixed ePub 2
  • - flowing ePub 3
  • - fixed ePub 3
  • - PDF

HYBRID LOGOS

A tweak of the HPC logo with different fonts, presented here as an animated GIF, but it could be fixed and generated randomly every time the page is refreshed.

… or the different versions could be used for specific objects…

Special features

The style library will include many features for various uses and types of reports.

Dropped initials. In a written or published work, an initial is a letter at the beginning of a word, a chapter, or a paragraph that is larger than the rest of the text. The word is derived from the Latin initialis, which means standing at the beginning. An initial often is several lines in height and in older books or manuscripts, sometimes ornately decorated. In illuminated manuscripts, initials with images inside them, such as those illustrated here, are known as historiated initials. They were an invention of the Insular art of the British Isles in the eighth century. Initials containing, typically, plant-form spirals with small figures of animals or humans that do not represent a specific person or scene are known as “inhabited” initials. Certain important initials, such as the B of Beatus vir... at the opening of Psalm 1 at the start of a vulgate Latin psalter, could occupy a whole page of a manuscript. [wikipedia]

II

A chapter is one of the main divisions of a piece of writing of relative length, such as a book of prose, poetry, or law. In each case, chapters can be numbered or titled or both. An example of a chapter that has become well known is “Down the Rabbit-Hole”, which is the first chapter from Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland. The “§” symbol is commonly used to represent a chapter.

In works of fiction, authors sometimes number their chapters eccentrically, often as a metafictional statement. For example:

  • The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time by Mark Haddon only has chapters which are prime numbers.
  • At Swim-Two-Birds by Flann O'Brien has the first page titled Chapter 1, but has no further chapter divisions.
  • God, A Users Guide by Seán Moncrieff is chaptered backwards (i.e., the first chapter is chapter 20 and the last is chapter 1). The novel The Running Man by Stephen King also uses a similar chapter numbering scheme.
  • Every novel in the series A Series of Unfortunate Events by Lemony Snicket has thirteen chapters, except the final installment (The End), which has a fourteenth chapter formatted as its own novel.
  • Mammoth by John Varley, has the chapters ordered in chronological order from the point of view of a non-time-traveler, but, as most of the characters travel through time, this leads to the chapters defying the conventional order [wikipedia]

And many more features to come!
